Check of 4 basic functions using the integrator:
The first function gives: 0.666953909054655 and should equal 2/3
The second function gives: 1.99996150007805 and should equal 2
The third function gives: 3.14183457802727 and should equal pi
The fourth function gives: -3.99991705899915 and should equal -4
The error margin is set to be 0.001 

Deviation from tabulated values for this error function in comparrison to the one from lecture 6

 The worst accuracy is at 1.9, so now we check for lower epsilons if it is possible to get a better accuracy
0.001 0.000707728943909913 9.50233592922345E-08
0.0001 -3.12235243156156E-05 9.50233592922345E-08
1E-05 -2.06324102718369E-05 9.50233592922345E-08
1E-06 -7.94490508937429E-08 9.50233592922345E-08
1E-07 -4.30924840255642E-09 9.50233592922345E-08
1E-08 -7.05551506108293E-10 9.50233592922345E-08
1E-09 -2.47909803796631E-10 9.50233592922345E-08
1E-10 -2.44338549393319E-10 9.50233592922345E-08
Thus we achieve a better accuracy when epsilon and delta become small enough
